Home Football Jude Bellingham shows off her new style when collaborating with fashion house Gucci

Jude Bellingham shows off her new style when collaborating with fashion house Gucci

Football Emily · 27/08/2023 · Real Madrid

Jude had to cultivate a love for football over time. He opted to play tag instead of football during his neighborhood's Saturday morning practices, but at age 7, he caught the bug and began his academy career with Birmingham City Football Club, where he lasted for 10 years.

In January 2015, an 11-year-old Birmingham kid named Jude Bellingham was enjoying the last few days of his Christmas holiday after only starting secondary school the previous term. He liked Caribbean food and Batman, just like most young people his age, and he also wanted to hang out with his friends. 

Football was another passion of his: "All day, every day, any moment I could get to play football, I was playing; break time, lunchtime at school, and then I'd leave school, come home, and then play outdoors for a bit with my buddies on the little piece of grass... So, basically, football was all we did," he remembers.

Alessandro Michele received notice of his appointment to Creative Director of the fashion house at the Gucci menswear presentation in January 2015. Michele, a Roman who has been with the firm for 13 years and is knowledgeable about its history, took over as CEO of Gucci with a specific objective in mind. He created the Love Parade collection for this spring/summer to beautifully encapsulate his now-famous Romantic eclecticism philosophy, which undoubtedly encouraged people's desire for individuality and character in apparel.

Without a doubt, this approach has attracted a young audience that is ready to discover methods to honor innovation and its distinct personality. Jude Bellingham is also a member of that generation. one who believes strongly in self-expression. I always try to be sincere, the football player claims. Even though I may have already caused some issues with my interviews this season, I always feel like it's just me speaking; it's never my "brand" or how I believe I should communicate in order to avoid offending anyone. Therefore, it is always me, whether it be on the field, in my behavior off the field, or both. I simply try to be myself because I am a respectful person, and I know that.
